docs.lead_paragraph: It’s clear that diet and genes contribute to how fat you are. But a new wave of scientific research suggests that, for some people, there might be a third factor — microorganisms.

docs.lead_paragraph: China confirmed that a soldier died of the A(H5N1) avian flu strain in 2003, two years before the country publicly acknowledged its first human infection.

headline.main: China: Ministry Confirms First Bird Flu Death Was in 2003
headline.print_headline: CHINA: MINISTRY CONFIRMS FIRST BIRD FLU DEATH WAS IN 2003

docs.snippet: China confirmed that a soldier died of the A(H5N1) avian flu strain in 2003, two years before the country publicly acknowledged its first human infection.

docs.lead_paragraph: China confirmed that a soldier died of the A(H5N1) avian flu strain in 2003, two years before the country publicly acknowledged its first human infection, in a case that raised questions about Beijing's ability to detect new emerging diseases. The 24-year-old man was thought to have had SARS, but recent tests performed with the World Health Organization confirmed that he had bird flu, the Health Ministry said on its Web site. A W.H.O. spokesman said the agency was urging Beijing to re-examine similar cases of unknown origin. But a ministry spokesman said that the 2003 case was not evidence of a bird flu outbreak in China at that time and that there were no plans to review other cases. The soldier's case was disclosed in June in a letter to The New England Journal of Medicine by Chinese researchers. China publicly announced its first human case of bird flu in November 2005, as the virus was tearing though Vietnam and Thailand. The ministry statement gave no indication where the soldier might have contracted the disease.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Ministry Confirms First Bird Flu Death Was In 2003

docs.abstract: Chinese Health Ministry confirms that soldier died of avian flu strain in 2003, two years prior to government's acknowledgement of first human infection from virus; recent World Health Organization tests confirmed bird flu, but prior diagnosis had been SARS virus; WHO urges China to re-examine similar cases for potential misdiagnoses (S)
